subject: RE: [junit] Threshholds for (J)Unit Testing
msgSnippet: ... I don t follow you here - why shouldn t it be interesting to someone looking at a testcase class to know which category it belongs to? ... I don t see any
messageBody:
> Actually, I think the interface marker hack is worse than
> prefixing your methods with "tests", because it actually
> changes the type of your class for no benefit to your
> business logic or future readers of your code. This kind of
> information should not appear in JavaDoc nor with javap: it
> should be completely hidden and available only to the tool that will
> use it.

I don't follow you here - why shouldn't it be interesting to someone looking
at a testcase class to know which category it belongs to?

> Also, you can quickly see how using this trick to implement
> groups of tests can lead to a combinatorial explosion of
> interfaces and to classes that implement five or ten
> different interfaces... Not very clean.

I don't see any combinatorial explosion of interfaces - we would have one
interface per category, which sounds more like a "linear explosion" to me...
;)

I also don't see a big difference between a test class implementing five or
ten interfaces or using five or ten annotations. Am I missing something?

Cheers, Ilja
